Message.Title: Judge Approves BAC Settlement.
Message.Msg: Bank of America on Friday won a federal judge’s approval for a $2.43 billion settlement with investors who said the lender hid crucial information when it bought Merrill Lynch. The accord, among the largest investor settlements stemming from the recent global financial crisis, was approved by Federal District Judge P. Kevin Castel in Manhattan. Judge Castel called the settlement “fair, reasonable and adequate.” Shareholders said Merrill’s mounting losses and bonus plans should have been disclosed before investors voted on the merger in December 2008. Bank of America denied the plaintiffs’ claims, but the chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, has said the settlement would remove uncertainty for bank.

Message.Title: BOA lawsuit progress
Message.Msg: From BAC 10-Q and recent articles: BOA has paid ~$40B to resolve claims related to CW's origination of faulty mortgages including a [$2.43 billion] class action settlement and a [$165 million] settlement with NCUA this week by shareholders over the acquisition of Merrill Lynch. To summarize the major settlements to date and the remaining liabilities - BOA faces liability under three legal categories - 1) Mortgage servicing • Banking Industry Regulators (OCC & FRB) - [settled $2.5B] • US Justice Dep't & 49 State AG's - [settled $10.8B] 2) Securities fraud 20+ cases (AIG, FHFA, etc) in federal court in California that address claims of securities fraud: • Based on recent securities fraud settlements (Citi, Wells, Deutsche), BOA's potential estimated exposure is range of [$2.6 - $3.9 billion]; however, if • Based on a separate securities fraud potential settlement (UBS v FHFA), BOA's potential estimated exposure could be higher, a possible reasonable securities fraud overall range of [$5 - $15 billion.] 3) Breach of contract • Federal Housing Agency - [settled $1B] • Freddie Mac - [settled $1.2B] • Fannie Mae - [settled $8.8B] • US Justice Dept - [remaining $1 billion pending] • Private institutions (Pimco, BlackRock,etc) - [remaining $8.5 billion pending judicial approval] • Other Private institutions - [remaining $6.5 billion pending] • Bond Insurers (MBIA,etc) - [settled $2B; remaining $6 billion pending] BOA has some reserves to cover the current pending liability... not sure what they have reserved. One interesting note is that BOA has a case pending against MBIA re restructuring - if the outcome is favorable for BOA, it will dampen/neutralize the amount BOA may owe to MBIA re the MBIA case against BOA. The above estimates and the possible final remaining settlement amounts could be more/less and are TBD... but the good news is that BOA is making progress towards putting these uncertainties behind.

Message.Title: What should the minimum wage be?
Message.Msg: Suppose the minimum wage 50 years ago was just $1 per hour, here are four ways to figure what the equivalent should be today. If you want to compare the value of a $1.00 Income or Wealth , in 1960 there are four choices. In 2011 the relative: historic standard of living value of that income or wealth is $7.59 contemporary standard of living value of that income or wealth is $8.83 economic status value of that income or wealth is $16.60 economic power value of that income or wealth is $28.70

Topic.Title: What should the minimum wage be?

Message.Msg: Or to make it more clear. In 1960, the minimum wage was $1.00 an hour. Here's what some basics cost in 1960: New house; $11,700 Average monthly rent: $88 Gas: 22c a gallon New car: $2,050 Health insurance for family: $75 a month In 2008, the minimum wage was $6.55 an hour. Here are the costs in 2008: New house: $212,000 Average monthly rent: $1,200 Gas: $2.25 a gallon New car: $28,400 Health insurance for family: $840 a month The costs increased, on these basics, by a factor of 13 since 1960. To have the same standard of living as Americans enjoyed in 1960, the minimum wage in 2008 should have been $13 an hour. today it would be even more.

Topic.Title: BOA lawsuit progress

Message.Msg: thx for above replies... that is a decent reserve level. I don't think there were any major payouts/settlements during 1Q13, therefore, BOA's earnings could be ok and they s/b able to continue building on reserve levels if necessary. I believe they are in a good position to start clearing the deck of the remaining litigation. BOA mentioned they hope to settle the $8.5B private suit in late 2Q/early 3Q. And, yes, it appears MBIA is trying to have it both ways... I think BOA's claim against MBIA re hiding funds/restructuring to avoid payouts is on point and that one will hopefully work out favorably to BOA. Not sure if when they settle and pay claims from reserves if it has an impact on the Qtr earnings or not? For example, haven't they already booked the $8.5 pending claim and when they settle and pay, that amt will not impact the upcoming 2nd or 3rd Q right?

Message.Title: Huge March Madness Play
Message.Msg: It was just announced that there were 45 million online streams of the NCAA March Madness Basketball Tournament games so far this year, up 158% from last year, with 60% of them over mobile devices! Concurrent (CCUR) is an undiscovered and extremely undervalued low float stock that will capitalize most on this! CCUR's MediaHawk multi-screen technology can deliver any format of video, to any screen/device, at any time, over any network. CCUR was the first company to introduce video on demand (VOD) technology over a decade ago and today they hold a 30% market share of the VOD space with 212 VOD deployments across 4 continents and a reach of 50mm VOD homes. CCUR's clients include Time Warner Cable, Cox, Charter, and Bright House. CCUR ran from $7 to over $200 during the original VOD boom and now we are about to experience a boom of pay-TV companies rushing to upgrade their VOD infrastructure to support multi-screen video delivery to tablets and smartphones. CCUR just signed Virgin Media (VMED) the largest cable TV company in the UK with 3.8mm subscribers. CCUR will be powering VMED's brand new Virgin TV Anywhere service that allows their subscribers to watch content over their tablets and smartphones. CCUR has also signed a huge multi-screen deal with the largest cable TV company in Japan. CCUR closed last week at $7.24 per share with only 9.2mm shares outstanding and a market cap of $66.6mm with $24.6mm in cash, no debt, and an enterprise value of only $42mm or just 0.67X its revenue of $62.59mm! CCUR's EPS has been ramping up big on a quarter-to-quarter basis from $0.02 to $0.04 and to $0.08. Their main competitor Seachange (SEAC) is losing money, yet it's trading with an enterprise value/revenue ratio of 1.81, which would value CCUR at $15. CCUR's gross margins of 58.81% exceed SEAC's gross margins of 50.18% CCUR has potential to at least double this month.

Topic.Title: Would the latest settlement hurt the coming earning?

Message.Msg: Per Reuters: BAC "still faces a variety of litigation over its mortgage operations, which have shrunk significantly in size, and over its underwriting of mortgage securities. Bank of America is among 17 banks and lenders facing lawsuits by the Federal Housing Finance Agency over losses suffered by Fannie Mae (FNMA.OB) and Freddie Mac (FMCC.OB) on mortgage securities. The FHFA has sued Bank of America over $57.5 billion of securities, more than any other bank, that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac bought, and which were sponsored or underwritten by Bank of America, Countrywide or Merrill." Plus economy at its peak and about to tank. This is good news for now but if BAC was to lose the remaining lawsuits, it wouldn't have half the $$ to cover the judgements. I'd say BAC could be a good short-term (days) position but nothing beyond that.
